articles.title: Robots descend into lava tubes to prepare for future Moon bases
articles.summary: Hidden lava tunnels on the Moon and Mars could one day shelter human explorers, offering natural protection from radiation and space debris. A European research team has unveiled a bold new mission concept that uses three different robots working together to explore these extreme underground environments autonomously. Recently tested in the volcanic caves of Lanzarote, the system maps cave entrances, deploys sensors, lowers a scout rover, and creates detailed 3D maps of the interior.
articles.content:
Lava tunnels on nearby planetary bodies are increasingly seen as strong candidates for future base camps. These underground structures can naturally shield astronauts from harmful radiation and frequent meteorite impacts. Despite their promise, reaching and studying these environments is extremely challenging due to rough terrain, limited entry points, and dangerous conditions.

To tackle these challenges, a European research consortium that includes the Space Robotics Laboratory at the University of Malaga has developed a new mission concept focused on exploring lava tunnels. The work was recently published in the journal Science Robotics. The concept centers on three different types of robots that can work together autonomously to explore and map these harsh underground spaces. The system is currently being tested in volcanic caves in Lanzarote (Spain), with future missions aimed at the Moon.

Four Phases of Autonomous Exploration

The proposed mission unfolds in four carefully planned stages. First, the robots cooperatively map the area around the lava tunnel entrance (phase 1). Next, a sensorized payload cube is dropped into the cave to gather initial measurements (phase 2). A scout rover then rappels down through the entrance to reach the interior (phase 3). In the final stage, the robotic team explores the tunnel in depth and produces detailed 3D maps of its interior (phase 4).

A real world field test conducted on Lanzarote in February 2023 showed that the approach works as planned. The trial highlighted the technical capabilities of the consortium led by the German Research Center for Artificial Intelligence (DFKI), with contributions from the University of Malaga and the Spanish company GMV.

Preparing for the Moon and Mars

The results confirmed that the mission concept is technically feasible and demonstrated the broader potential of collaborative robotic systems. These findings suggest that teams of autonomous robots could play a key role in future exploration missions to the Moon or Mars. The study also supports continued development of advanced robotic technologies for planetary exploration.

The Role of the Space Robotics Laboratory at the UMA

The Space Robotics Laboratory at the UMA focuses on creating new methods and technologies that increase autonomy in space robotics, covering both planetary and orbital missions. In recent years, the laboratory has worked closely with the European Space Agency, developing algorithms that help planetary exploration vehicles (rovers) plan routes and operate more independently.

Beyond research, the laboratory is dedicated to training the next generation of space robotics engineers. Students from the School of Industrial Engineering at UMA participate in internships and thesis projects related to this work. Most projects are carried out in partnership with national and international research institutions through joint research efforts or technology transfer agreements with companies and research organizations.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant technological advancement in autonomous robotic exploration of lunar and Martian lava tubes, which could provide natural shelters for future human bases. This has broad implications for space exploration and human safety on other planets. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights successful real-world testing, demonstrating tangible progress toward enabling human space colonization.

articles.title: A huge cloud of dark matter may be lurking near our solar system
articles.summary: For the first time, researchers have found what seems to be a cloud of dark matter about 60 million times the mass of the sun in our galactic neighbourhood
articles.content:
For the first time, researchers have found what seems to be a cloud of dark matter about 60 million times the mass of the sun in our galactic neighbourhood

There might be a big clump of dark matter in our galactic neighbourhood Alamy

There seems to be an enormous cloud of dark matter next to our solar system. We have never found one of these clouds in the Milky Way before, but precise cosmic clocks called pulsars finally made it possible.

Our best cosmological models hold that galaxies are embedded in tenuous clouds of dark matter called halos, with smaller sub-halos studded throughout. But dark matter doesn’t emit, absorb or reflect light, so halos and especially sub-halos are extraordinarily difficult to find.

To spot this one, Sukanya Chakrabarti at the University of Alabama in Huntsville and her colleagues used pairs of rapidly spinning neutron stars called pulsars. Pulsars spin at an astonishingly regular rate, sweeping beams of light across the sky as they do so, which makes them crucial cosmic clocks. With a pair of them, we can use changes in their orbits around one another to measure the acceleration that occurs when a massive object is nearby.

Dark matter interacts with regular matter via gravity, so if a dark matter sub-halo is near a pair of pulsars, it should stretch their orbits slightly. That is exactly what Chakrabarti and her colleagues found a little more than 3000 light years from our solar system. “There’s one pair of pulsars and the [individual] pulsars around it – there’s something in this part of the sky that’s pulling all of these pulsars in this weird direction that we didn’t expect,” says team member Philip Chang at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee.

The researchers analysed the extent of the pull and found that it must come from an object about 60 million times the mass of the sun, measuring several hundred light years across. They compared the location of the mysterious, massive object with maps of stars, gas and other objects made of regular matter, finding no matches. If the object is truly there, which the researchers say isn’t definitively confirmed yet, it must be dark matter.

If so, it could be the only sub-halo of its size in our corner of the galaxy. “There might only be one or two locally, but it depends on the model of dark matter,” says Alice Quillen at the University of Rochester in New York. “Different models predict different distributions of these clumps.”

That is what set Chakrabarti on the path of hunting sub-halos in the first place. “Our goal is to map out as many of these sub-halos as we can across the galaxy, and we’ve just started being able to do that. Then the ultimate goal is to understand the nature of dark matter,” she says.

However, pulsar binaries are relatively rare: there are only 27 for which we have observations precise enough to measure their acceleration due to gravity, which is part of why this sub-halo wasn’t found before now. “The amount of pulsars is finite, so we’re trying to come up with other ways to trace this with objects that are more numerous,” says Chang. If they are able to do so, we may finally have a crucial tool for probing what dark matter really is.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific discovery of a large dark matter cloud near our solar system, using innovative methods with pulsars. This finding advances our understanding of dark matter, a major unsolved problem in astrophysics, with broad implications for cosmology and space science. The story is focused, detailed, and describes a breakthrough with potential wide impact on scientific knowledge.
articles.personality_title: Scientists find huge dark matter cloud near our solar system
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Dark matter is a mysterious substance that makes up much of the universe but cannot be seen because it does not give off or reflect light. Scientists believe dark matter forms large, invisible clouds called halos around galaxies, but finding these clouds is very hard.

**What happened** – A team of researchers led by Sukanya Chakrabarti used pairs of special stars called pulsars, which act like precise cosmic clocks, to detect the presence of a massive dark matter cloud. They found this cloud about 3,000 light years away from our solar system. The cloud is about 60 million times heavier than the sun and stretches several hundred light years across.

**Impact** – This is the first time such a large dark matter cloud, or sub-halo, has been found so close to us. It shows a new way to study dark matter by watching how its gravity pulls on pulsars. Since dark matter is one of the biggest mysteries in space science, this discovery could help scientists learn more about what it is and how it behaves.

**What’s next step** – The researchers want to find more dark matter clouds by studying more pulsars and other objects that might show similar effects. Because pulsar pairs are rare, they are also looking for new methods to detect dark matter. This could lead to better maps of dark matter in our galaxy and a deeper understanding of the universe.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Using pulsars as cosmic clocks, scientists have found a massive dark matter cloud near our solar system, opening a new path to study this invisible substance.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques découvrent un immense nuage de matière noire près de notre système solaire
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La matière noire est une substance mystérieuse qui compose une grande partie de l’univers, mais qu’on ne peut pas voir car elle ne produit ni ne réfléchit la lumière. Les scientifiques pensent que la matière noire forme de grands nuages invisibles appelés halos autour des galaxies, mais les détecter est très difficile.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une équipe de chercheurs dirigée par Sukanya Chakrabarti a utilisé des paires d’étoiles spéciales appelées pulsars, qui fonctionnent comme des horloges cosmiques très précises, pour détecter un énorme nuage de matière noire. Ils ont trouvé ce nuage à environ 3 000 années-lumière de notre système solaire. Ce nuage a une masse environ 60 millions de fois celle du Soleil et s’étend sur plusieurs centaines d’années-lumière.

**Impact** – C’est la première fois qu’un nuage aussi grand de matière noire, ou sous-halo, est découvert aussi près de nous. Cette découverte montre une nouvelle méthode pour étudier la matière noire en observant comment sa gravité attire les pulsars. Puisque la matière noire est l’un des plus grands mystères de la science spatiale, cette avancée pourrait aider les scientifiques à mieux comprendre sa nature et son comportement.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs veulent trouver d’autres nuages de matière noire en étudiant plus de pulsars et d’autres objets pouvant montrer des effets similaires. Comme les paires de pulsars sont rares, ils cherchent aussi de nouvelles méthodes pour détecter la matière noire. Cela pourrait permettre de mieux cartographier la matière noire dans notre galaxie et d’approfondir notre connaissance de l’univers.

**En une phrase** – Grâce aux pulsars comme horloges cosmiques, des scientifiques ont découvert un immense nuage de matière noire près de notre système solaire, ouvrant une nouvelle voie pour étudier cette substance invisible.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos encuentran una enorme nube de materia oscura cerca de nuestro sistema solar
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La materia oscura es una sustancia misteriosa que forma gran parte del universo, pero no puede verse porque no emite ni refleja luz. Los científicos creen que la materia oscura forma grandes nubes invisibles llamadas halos alrededor de las galaxias, pero encontrarlas es muy difícil.

**Qué pasó** – Un equipo de investigadores liderado por Sukanya Chakrabarti usó pares de estrellas especiales llamadas púlsares, que funcionan como relojes cósmicos muy precisos, para detectar una enorme nube de materia oscura. Encontraron esta nube a unos 3,000 años luz de nuestro sistema solar. La nube tiene una masa unas 60 millones de veces mayor que la del sol y se extiende por varios cientos de años luz.

**Impacto** – Es la primera vez que se encuentra una nube tan grande de materia oscura, o subhalo, tan cerca de nosotros. Esto muestra una nueva forma de estudiar la materia oscura observando cómo su gravedad afecta a los púlsares. Dado que la materia oscura es uno de los mayores misterios de la ciencia espacial, este descubrimiento podría ayudar a los científicos a entender mejor qué es y cómo funciona.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores quieren encontrar más nubes de materia oscura estudiando más púlsares y otros objetos que puedan mostrar efectos similares. Como los pares de púlsares son raros, también buscan nuevos métodos para detectar la materia oscura. Esto podría llevar a mapas más detallados de la materia oscura en nuestra galaxia y a un mejor conocimiento del universo.

**Una frase clave** – Usando púlsares como relojes cósmicos, los científicos han encontrado una enorme nube de materia oscura cerca de nuestro sistema solar, abriendo un nuevo camino para estudiar esta sustancia invisible.
